The Numbers Don't Lie

When Reform UK took control of Lancashire County Council in May 2025, they inherited a financial crisis: a £28 million projected overspend, a savings delivery rate of just 48%, a concealed £350 million bond portfolio loss, and the joint-lowest CQC adult social care rating of any county council in England.

Nine months later, the transformation is measurable.

Overspend: £28M to Near Zero

The £28 million projected overspend — inherited in its entirety from the previous Conservative administration — has been systematically eliminated. By Q2 (September 2025), it was reduced to £10.4 million. By December 2025, it stood at £6.2 million. By January 2026, Leader Stephen Atkinson reported the gap had "nearly disappeared to zero."

That represents approximately 2.5% of the council's £1.2 billion net budget recovered in just eight months — a pace of fiscal correction that few councils have achieved.

Savings Delivery: From 48% to 100% Target

The previous Conservative administration set a savings target of £68.6 million for 2024/25. They delivered just £32.9 million — a 48% delivery rate. More than £35 million in planned savings simply never materialised.

Reform has set a £60 million savings target for 2025/26 and is targeting 100% delivery. The efficiency review completed in November 2025 identified an additional £22 million in savings over three years across contracts, procurement, property, and digital transformation.

Council Tax: Lowest Rise in 12 Years

Reform's proposed 2026/27 council tax rise of 3.80% (1.8% core + 2.0% adult social care precept) is the lowest increase Lancashire has seen in 12 years. The Conservatives raised council tax to the legal maximum without a referendum — 4.99% — in their final two years. Their highest ever rise was 5.99% in 2018/19.

Councillor Allowances: Frozen

Reform led a near-unanimous vote (75-0, with 3 Lib Dem abstentions) to reject all proposed councillor pay increases, saving between £92,000 and £115,000 annually.

Agency Staff: £1.5M Reduction

Agency staffing costs are now tracking £1.5 million below levels from 12 months prior — a direct result of better workforce planning and reduced reliance on expensive temporary staff.

Roads: 42% Defect Reduction

Road defects have been reduced by 42% in the first six months. The council has allocated £28 million specifically for pothole and structural repairs, with an additional £5 million emergency cabinet decision for responsive patching, resurfacing, and road markings. A total of £45 million has been pledged over three years.

SEND: 677 New Places

277 additional SEND pupil places were created in 2025, with a further 400 new spaces announced in February 2026. A new 200+ pupil special school is to be built by 2027. Over £3 million per year in additional investment has been committed to Educational Psychology services.

The Context Critics Ignore

Every piece of criticism directed at Reform's record at LCC must be weighed against what they inherited: a council where the previous administration failed to deliver more than half its own savings targets, concealed a £350 million bond portfolio loss, maxed out council tax rises year after year, and left adult social care rated joint-worst of any county council in England.

Reform didn't create these problems. They're fixing them — and the data proves it.
